title: Clock fanatic has to turn back dials on all 5,000 of his timepieces this weekend
text:
Roy West really likes clocks, in case you hadn’t noticed (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive.com)

A pensioner who really loves clocks is set to spend five hours turning back the dials on his 5,000 timepieces.

Roy West, 75, has been collecting clocks for almost 40 years and has covered practically every inch of wall space in his two bedroom flat with them.

He has more than 30 bedside clocks, 60 in his bathroom and hundreds more tucked away in cupboards.

The flat is home to 25 Westminster clocks which chime every 5 minutes – meaning Roy and his 68-year-old wife Pauline should have no excuses for missing an appointment.

With the clocks going back at 2am on Sunday morning, Roy will spend his Saturday night turning back his entire collection to fall in with Greenwhich Meantime.

He started collecting them in the 1980s after his boss threw away a perfectly good one (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive.com)

He previously left the task to his wife, who would take three days to adjust all the hands.

Roy, from Chandler’s Ford, Hampshire, said: ‘I start in the bedroom, because I have the most in there. That room alone takes an hour-and-a-half.

‘I then go into the living room and that will take me an hour, then do the hallway, kitchen, bathroom and all the cupboards.

‘There’s a lot in my cupboards. Finally I do the clocks in the spare room, which takes another hour.”

‘It’s a long job but I don’t mind. I don’t want any of my clocks telling the wrong time.’

His wall is lined with timepieces, making it impossible for him not to be aware of the time (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive.com)

He has well over 5,000 now and says he will never stop buying them (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive.com)

The retired van driver started collecting timepieces in 1980 after his boss chucked one in the bin.

They said it didn’t work, but all it needed was a new battery, Roy explained.

From there, he started scouring charity shops and buying as many clocks as he could.

He added: ‘It all started from there. It’s taken a long time but I’ve now built up a collection of well over 5,000 clocks.

‘Pauline brings home a new pack of batteries every time she goes to the shops just to make sure none of them ever stop.’

His wife used to spend three days changing all the hands (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive.com)

The constant ticking doesn’t seem to bother Roy anymore (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive)

The noise in Roy and Pauline’s bedroom alone is enough to keep most people awake all night.

But the collector, who believes his collection is worth upwards of £1,500, insists he no longer hears the constant ticking.

He added: ‘I don’t take any notice of the noise

‘I’ve got 30 by the bed and more on the walls in the bedroom, but you just get used to it.

‘It’s like when all my Westminster chime clocks go off.

‘I’ve got about 25 of those but they’re all adjusted to go off at the same time, so it doesn’t bother us.’

He has even more in storage at a family member’s house (Picture: Paul Jacobs/pictureexclusive)

Along with all the timepieces in his flat, Roy also has boxes full tucked away in storage at a family member’s house after the couple’s shed blew down in bad weather.

But once he has bought a new one, he will get to work and begin hammering clocks to the walls in there too.

Roy said: ‘I’ll never stop buying clocks. Once I get some storage space sorted out, I can get the others back from my relative.

‘I’ll put them in the shed and try and get some more on the walls in my flat.

‘I will rearrange them so I can squeeze more in.’
